Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2013 06:02AM nesw wrote: SophiaMarie - I just wanted to add to what everyone else has said in the hopes of helping you find a speck of calm in all of this.  I had a double mastectomy within a few weeks of a routine mammogram.  After multiple imagery and biopsies, it went from one spot of DCIS to multiple spots, one of which had begun to invade out of the duct.  At the time, it was a whirlwind and I was focused on what was happening day to day.  It's been 10 months since surgery and I've been in therapy and now on antidepressants for stress disorder/depression.  I eat a small breakfast, usually almond butter and apples on toast, no lunch, and some dinner, usually a chunky soup or a veggie burger.  I have a tiny bit of wine with dinner too.  I've lost nearly 20 pounds without trying and I sit with my computer a lot.  I'm just not hungry and I don't feel like doing anything.  It hit me like a ton of bricks and I hear from other women that's normal.  I'm breathing deeply and trying to live the moment and I'm forcing myself to try to just do my normal things that used to make me happy.  I know other women have had much more devastating diagnoses and my heart breaks for them.  I've actually started crying reading some of the women's posts.  All of us have one thing in common - this stinking disease and our personal grieving.  I think for some the grieving is more frantic and some more depressive, but I think it's all normal.  We're all hugging you and hoping to help you through this together.
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2013 09:31AM nesw wrote: I'm being treated for stress disorder/depression with cognitive therapy and antidepressant.  My internist recognized it during a regular appointment and got the ball rolling.  It's been 8 months since my bmx, and I didn't even have chemo.  All stemming from a routine mammogram leading to u/s to MRI to multiple biopsies, and things snowballed from one spot of DCIS that would've required lumpectomy, to multiple regions of DCIS that required mx.  Then they went back for my nipples after finding the invasion behind one of them.  Within a matter of six weeks, my whole world changed.  I consider myself a fairly strong person, but I just kinda got lost, really lost.  To think of those of you diagnosed with more progressed disease requiring the onslaught of chemo or radiation, it is heart-wrenching.  And I think about it ALL the time.
Posts.Title: PTSD and Mastectomy vs Lumpectomy farmerlucy farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2013 09:04AM nesw wrote: I went to my internal med doc in Mar (following surgery at end of Dec) and told him I thought I had brain damage from anesthesia. He told me they were symptoms of depression and were normal, that I was grieving the loss of my old self. I do think I needed the Lexapro, but after my early July surgery, I spent the summer sitting around looking at things to do and not knowing how to get started on so many things. Even cooking one meal, I would find myself standing there trying to remember what I was going to do next. Based on my experience, I would say between 2-3 months after surgery I just START to feel better.
Posts.Title: Memory Loss and or Confusion myers421 jeni72

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2013 10:51AM nesw wrote: I have this also, very seriously, and I'm a science teacher too. I've attributed it to the anesthesia in the past year (about 15 hours total in four separate surgeries). I do feel more competent if I exercise; however, my internal med doctor put me on 10 mg daily Lexapro (he says depression) and 50,000 IU weekly D (low in bloodwork). I can concentrate on complex thinking for an issue at hand, such as developing a PowerPoint presentation, but can't seem to plan out multiple things, like what to get at the grocery store for the next few days of meals. And it seems like I have such a vocabulary loss - that's what bother's me most. I've been on the Lexapro and D since this past March, and I really felt good after about a month of it, but I had my 3rd and 4th surgery in July and October. I remember feeling really good during September when school started, so I'm convinced the anesthesia has a strong effect and it will wear off again over the next month. However, I do feel like I need the Lexapro and D also.
Posts.Title: Memory Loss and or Confusion myers421 jeni72

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2013 10:52AM nesw wrote: Just to let you know my experience - I had a routine mammogram that showed an "assymmetry" in my right breast.  Called back for targeted ultrasound, which was inconclusive.  With my mother who died from metastasized breast cancer (diagnosed age 75 at stage IV), I was considered high risk and was sent directly to a breast surgeon who ordered a breast MRI with contrast.  The MRI identified another region, not even seen on mammo or ultrasound, that was suspicious.  Both biopsied - the assymmetry turned out to be benign fybrocystic change, the other was DCIS.  This led to more biopsies because of things only seen on MRI.  Things snowballed from there to where I've now had double mastectomy and I have expanders in.  I'm not saying it's common to have occult cancers like I did - my breasts were very dense - but I thought it was common to go with an MRI when mammos or ultrasounds are inconclusive. If they had simply biopsied my assymmetry after the mammo and ultrasound and found benign fibrocystic change, I would be in trouble because I would still have three regions of DCIS, and one of them was already microinvasive. I would request a breast specialist and at least ask about MRI.
Posts.Title: Why am I not high-risk? bean bean
Would you mind sharing your age at time of diagnosis? ByFaith Gussy

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2013 08:50PM nesw wrote: After an asymmetry was seen on my mammogram and a follow up ultrasound was inconclusive, my dense breasts were ordered to have an MRI with contrast (mainly because I was high risk because of my mother with breast cancer).  The MRI found my cancer - the asymmetry turned out to be nothing on biopsy, but the MRI led to a biopsy that found two regions of cancer.  Neither of these regions showed anything in mammo or ultrasound. If you feel you are high risk in any way, MRI is usually a good tool to assess dense breasts.
Posts.Title: dense breast and worried Mamabear67 Kay_G

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2013 10:40PM nesw wrote: I would definitely at least ask for MRI for dense breasts (or ask what the doctors think abour it).
